prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. Let me start by understanding the situation.

The author and their girlfriend live together. The author pays all the rent and bills because the girlfriend only works part-time. Then there's an incident where the author forgets their wallet and asks the girlfriend to pay for takeout under $40. The girlfriend's reaction is described as having an ugly attitude, being disgusted, and acting put out. The author is upset about this and now wants the girlfriend to start contributing to the bills, even though they acknowledge she can't pay a lot. The question is whether the author is in the wrong.

First, let's look at the dynamics. The author has been paying all the expenses, which is fine if they both agreed to it. However, the girlfriend works part-time, so maybe she doesn't earn much. The author expects her to contribute, but the amount she can contribute might be limited. The triggering event was a $40 takeout. The author is now considering making her pay some bills because of this one incident.

From a fairness perspective, if both partners live together, sharing expenses is usually expected, even if one earns more. The author might be right to want some contribution, but the approach could be an issue. However, the incident was over a small amount, and the girlfriend's reaction seems to be a problem. The author is upset because the girlfriend didn't take it well, leading to the author's frustration about splitting bills.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, if they suddenly decided to make the girlfriend pay bills without discussing it, that could be seen as unfair, especially if there wasn't prior agreement. The author might be overreacting to a minor incident. On the other hand, if the author has been covering all expenses while the girlfriend can contribute a small amount, it's reasonable to expect some sharing of costs. The key here is communication. If the author hasn't discussed splitting expenses before and is now making a unilateral decision based on one incident, that's probably the issue.

The girlfriend's reaction could be due to feeling disrespected or that her financial limitations aren't being considered. The author might be assuming that because she works part-time, she can contribute more than she actually can. The problem is that the author is using one incident to justify a broader change in financial responsibilities without considering the girlfriend's situation and without prior discussion. That could be seen as the author being in the wrong because it's a sudden shift and not considering mutual agreement.

So, the answer would be A (Yes, the author is in the wrong) if the author is making a unilateral decision without considering the girlfriend's perspective and prior agreement. Alternatively, if the author is just seeking a fair contribution based on the girlfriend's ability, then maybe not. But the way it's framed here, with the author reacting to a single incident and not discussing it, it's probably A.
